skull.brief: Protects the brain and houses sensory organs.
skull.innervation: Trigeminal nerve (sensory branches) and various motor branches for mastication muscles
skull.action: Protective bony vault for the brain; provides attachment for facial muscles
skull.clinicalPearl: Basilar skull fractures may present with raccoon eyes or Battle's sign — inspect carefully.

spine.brief: Supports the body and protects the spinal cord.
spine.innervation: Spinal nerves (31 pairs) exiting between vertebrae
spine.action: Axial support, load bearing, movement and neural protection
spine.clinicalPearl: Loss of vertebral height or step deformity on exam suggests compression fractures — check imaging.

ribs.brief: Form the rib cage to protect thoracic organs.
ribs.insertion: Anteriorly to the sternum (true ribs) or via costal cartilage (false ribs)
ribs.innervation: Intercostal nerves (ventral rami of thoracic spinal nerves)
ribs.action: Protection of thoracic organs and assistance with respiration
ribs.clinicalPearl: Flail chest (multiple adjacent rib fractures) can cause paradoxical chest wall motion; consider analgesia and respiratory support.

sternum.brief: Midline breastbone connecting the rib cage.
sternum.origin: Manubrium, body, xiphoid process (components of the sternum)
sternum.action: Central anchor for ribs and thoracic muscles
sternum.clinicalPearl: Sternal fractures commonly result from high-energy anterior chest trauma; evaluate for cardiac contusion if suspected.

humerus.origin: Proximal articulations with the scapula (glenohumeral joint)
humerus.insertion: Distally with radius and ulna at the elbow
humerus.action: Upper limb movement and force transmission
humerus.clinicalPearl: Proximal humeral fractures are common in older adults after a fall; check axillary nerve function (shoulder abduction) and vascular status.

radius.origin: Proximally articulates with humerus and ulna
radius.insertion: Distally forms part of the wrist (carpal bones)
radius.innervation: Radial and median nerve contributions to surrounding muscles
radius.action: Forearm rotation and load transmission to wrist
radius.clinicalPearl: Distal radius (Colles') fractures often occur from FOOSH; check for dinner-fork deformity.

ulna.brief: Medial forearm bone important for elbow stability.
ulna.insertion: Distally forms part of wrist articulation with radius
ulna.innervation: Ulnar nerve supplies intrinsic hand muscles and sensation medially
ulna.action: Forms hinge of elbow and stabilises forearm
ulna.clinicalPearl: Ulnar nerve injury at the elbow causes numbness/tingling in the little finger and weakness in finger abduction/adduction.

femur.brief: Thigh bone — longest and strongest bone.
femur.origin: Proximal articulation with pelvis at the hip
femur.innervation: Femoral nerve (anterior compartment) and sciatic nerve contributions
femur.clinicalPearl: A fractured femoral neck in older adults is an orthopedic emergency — stabilise and arrange urgent orthopedics.

tibia.brief: Shin bone — main weight-bearing bone of the lower leg.
tibia.insertion: Distal tibia forms ankle joint with talus
tibia.innervation: Tibial nerve for posterior compartment muscles
tibia.action: Weight bearing and forming knee/ankle joints
tibia.clinicalPearl: Tibial plateau fractures may impair knee stability — assess joint line tenderness and consider imaging with CT for surgical planning.

fibula.brief: Lateral lower-leg bone providing muscular attachment.
fibula.innervation: Common peroneal (fibular) nerve supplies associated muscles
fibula.action: Provides lateral support and muscle attachment; minor weight bearing
fibula.clinicalPearl: An isolated fibular head fracture may be associated with common peroneal nerve injury; examine dorsiflexion and sensation over the dorsum of the foot.

patella.brief: Kneecap — sesamoid bone in the quadriceps tendon.
patella.action: Protects knee joint and increases lever arm of quadriceps
patella.clinicalPearl: Patellar dislocation typically presents with lateral displacement and may require reduction; check extensor mechanism integrity.

pectoralis.brief: Large chest muscle involved in shoulder adduction and internal rotation.
pectoralis.insertion: Lateral lip of intertubercular sulcus of humerus
pectoralis.action: Adduction, internal rotation and flexion of humerus
pectoralis.clinicalPearl: Pectoralis major tendon ruptures are seen with heavy lifting; sudden pain and weakness on adduction should raise suspicion.

deltoid.origin: Lateral third of clavicle, acromion and spine of scapula
deltoid.action: Abduction, flexion, extension and rotation of the arm depending on fibres
deltoid.clinicalPearl: Axillary nerve injury from shoulder dislocation causes deltoid weakness and sensory loss over the lateral shoulder (regimental badge area).

biceps.brief: Anterior arm muscle for elbow flexion and supination.
biceps.origin: Long head from supraglenoid tubercle; short head from coracoid process
biceps.clinicalPearl: Biceps tendon rupture may present with a 'Popeye' deformity and weakness of supination.

quadriceps.brief: Anterior thigh muscle group for knee extension.
quadriceps.origin: Various heads from femur and iliac spine
quadriceps.insertion: Patella via quadriceps tendon to tibial tuberosity
quadriceps.action: Knee extension and hip flexion (rectus femoris)
quadriceps.clinicalPearl: Quadriceps tendon rupture results in inability to actively extend the knee; examine for suprapatellar gap.

gastrocnemius.action: Plantarflexion of the foot and knee flexion
gastrocnemius.clinicalPearl: Achilles tendon rupture commonly presents with a snapping sensation and difficulty with push-off; Thompson test can help diagnosis.
